31/ New twitter is the pulse of the world, machine curated for you.  (drops mic, catches breath, takes a drink of beer). peace.
30/ New Twitter is an enticing blend of stuff we know you want to engage on & stuff we think you might want to discover.
29/ The more you use it, the better & better it gets at serving up relevant content.
28/ For the most engaged, it’s what’s going on in my world, what’s happening to my posts, & other stuff i might care about it.
27/ For the more engaged it’s what’s going around in the world around me & relevant to me based on what I like & engage with.
26/ As a causal user it’s what’s going on in the world around me.
25/ The more you engage, better it gets. It’s Amazon / Netflix recommendations + Facebook newsfeed applied to the pulse of the world.
24/ Make the logged-in experience worth the engagement, not from a Tweeter perspective, but as a Follower.
23/ Personalize to develop more casual users into more active engaged users.
22/ Then, & this is the other half of the deal, the new Twitter must rapidly machine-learn based on occasional engagements & personalize.
21/ It’s the pulse of what’s going on right this minute, relevant to you.
20/ It’s Facebook for the real-world outside your immediate friends.
19/ Then checking back 50 times during the day.
18/ Twitter needs to be the one app people open in the morning with one eye shut to quickly find out what’s going on.
17/ Here are 3 stories we know you will be interested in based on your previous interactions or people you follow.
16/ Here’s what your network is talking about right now.
15/ And it’s collaboratively filtered and personalized to you.
14/ & it changes & updates by the second as the world changes.
13/ Except it’s not static TV content, it’s all live content & live conversations.
12/ It’s like turning on TV & having 1 screen that quickly shows you the 40 hottest shows right now.
11/ There’s no hunting, browsing, searching to find out what’s hot, it’s right there in front of you.
10/ Being fly-on-the-wall for real-time news, gossip, sports, commentary, served up in way that is filtered for you.
9/ It’s not about live events, it’s about live interactions & collaborative filtering.
8/ For casual 99.99% Twitter becomes place to discover what’s going on, & you’re hooked to it because it’s always immediately relevant.
7/ Build light features that enable 99.99% of people who only watch & follow to gain a shit-ton of value from the .1% who do most the work.
6/ Allow users to browse and follow conversations & topics; fave/like subscribe, as you ease them into being engaged users. @betashop
5/ Not tweets, rather the level above tweets: the meta hot topics/conversations.
4/ Smart Twitter feed (not current stream), provides real-time view into most relevant conversations, events, news; mix of nearby & topical.
3/ A new Twitter designed to bubble up relevant content, that grabs people’s attention & makes them more active over time. @betashop
2/ First, Twitter needs a very different feed, especially for inactive / logged-out users. @betashop
1/ A (probably obvious) recipe for improving Twitter in 3046 characters.

29/31 At Hem, over the past 9 months we did all 4 of these things. .@betashop @tweetsfromhem
28/31 At startup stage, make sure you have honesty, alignment, and people who are ready for the specific fight ahead. .@betashop
27/31 In startup, if you see people getting overly nervous when confronted with the truth, that’s something you must fix. .@betashop
26/31 In startup, everyone must get thrill from climbing mountains. Startup people find challenges invigorating, not scary. .@betashop
25/31 At startup stage, everyone must be a builder. .@betashop
24/31 People who joined one journey may not be suited for a different journey. .@betashop
23/31 People who join at the top may not have stomach for the valley. .@betashop
22/31 (4) Sometimes you need to change out people. Different people for different times. .@betashop
21/31 When your team figures how to advance and feels the energy of progress, that creates the culture. .@betashop
20/31  (3) show progress. Nothing establishes and changes culture more than putting wins on the board. .@betashop
19/31 People love to talk about empowerment. Real empowerment is knowing how your own actions contribute to the overall goal. @betashop
18/31 Everyone must know company goals, how measure success, personal expectations towards company goals .@betashop
17/31 (2) align objectives & key results (OKRs). .@betashop
16/31 It is critical to be honest and direct with your people about challenges. .@betashop
15/31 (1) brutal honesty. Here’s where we are; here are challenges we face; here’s what we need to do to overcome them. .@betashop
14/31 There are only 4 ways to fix company culture: .@betashop
13/31 So, we set out to fix that, and create a high-performance startup culture @ Hem @tweetsfromhem . .@betashop
12/31 1 of 3 companies had many people who joined a very different journey and didn't want to be part of the Hem journey. .@betashop
11/31 1 of 3 companies had never planned for nor experienced hyper growth. .@betashop
10/31 1 of the 3 companies just had traumatic & very public restructuring, shrinking from 750 employees to 125 in 15 months. .@betashop
9/31 Hem was formed by combining 3 different companies and 3 very different cultures. .@betashop
8/31 9 months ago when we started Hem, we faced a serious internal crisis of culture. @betashop @tweetsfromhem
7/31 That wasn't always the case @tweetsfromhem .@betashop.
6/31 Today, the company culture at Hem @tweetsfromhem is one of optimism, passion, and performance-driven results. .@betashop
5/31 Company culture is a perfect mirror on leadership values and actions. .@betashop
4/31 Company culture reflects the way the company actually works; the manner in which it gets shit done (or doesn’t). .@betashop
3/31 Company culture is created by doing. .@betashop
2/31 Company culture is not created by putting slogans on the walls.  .@betashop

How to raise $10M $30m $100m? That's a whole other tweet storm. .@betashop  some other day.
33/33 Even frothy markets are smart. If you can’t raise a seed round in this market, you are doing something wrong. .@betashop
32/33 get your seed round done fast. Seed times have never been so good. Get it while it's hot. And get back to work! @betashop
31/33 Talk to investments that went south. If the investors abandoned the entrepreneurs on shit days, avoid like the plague. @betashop
30/33 The best seed investors will still be there supporting you even when times suck. Sniff that out. .@betashop
29/33 The best seed investors invest in you more than your idea. .@betashop
28/33 the best sign of a good early-stage investor is that they are invested in you personally. .@betashop
27/33 Make sure your investor(s) will be there for you on shit days as well as good days. .@betashop
26/33 no matter how good you are, you will have plenty of shitty days ahead. .@betashop
25/33 raising money is a rush. But raising money doesn't grow a business. It only gives fuel to grow if u use it wisely. .@betashop
24/33 Always choose investor who really gets you & who really gets your business idea. Don't choose terms, choose people. .@betashop
23/33 choose the investor you want to work with over the one with the best terms. .@betashop
22/33 99% of time the extra million will matter more than the dilution. That's twice the runway to create value. .@betashop
21/33  If you have the choice of raising $1M or $2m at reasonable pre-revenue terms, always raise $2m. .@betashop
20/33 Only early-stage fools stress about dilution. Don't worry about dilution. .@betashop
19/33 So raise twice more than you need and give yours f twice the time. .@betashop
18/33 If you can't show traction by time of your Series A, you're fucked. .@betashop
17/33  Your seed round is raised off of people and ideas. A is raised off of traction. .@betashop
16/33  and raising your A round will be 10x harder than raising your seed round. .@betashop

15/33 raise twice what you need because you will need twice more than you think. 
 .@betashop
14/33 know exactly how much you need and raise twice that. .@betashop
13/33 Don’t try to create competition. Try to close a good deal. .@betashop

12/33 It only takes 1 term sheet to close a deal. 
 .@betashop
11/33 seek out a strong seed firm to lead your round. Focus all of your attention on 2 or 3 of those and land 1 or 2. @betashop

10/33 don't spend time pitching angels until you have your lead. 
 @betashop
9/33 when you ready to approach investors, go in buttoned up with a clear who, what, why, how, & how much.  @betashop

8/33 networking with investors is a waste of time. Spend time on your product. 
@betashop
7/33 don't meet with any investors unless you are ready to ask them for money. @betashop
.@betashop 6/33 everyone will want to meet with you. investors live for deal flow.
.@betashop 5/33 There’s more capital available for early-stage startups than ever before.
.@betashop 4/33 raising seed capital has never been easier.
.@betashop 3/33 here's what I told him.
.@betashop 2/33 smart alpha-stage founder sought my advice today on fundraising.
1/33 raising money. One of the few things I am certainly very good at.

40+4 Be the platform. Peace.
40+3 Focus on the usage.
40+2 They get this (See YouTube), the have the cash, they have the patience, and they’re not FB (nb I’m a long time FB investor too).
40+1/ Dear TWTR: Please go sell yourself to GOOG so Larry can fund 10- 30 year vision for  earth’s best 1-to-many publishing platform.
40/40 Or latch on to a partner (e.g. GOOG, MSFT) who is willing to support one. I vote GOOG (they know how to do this, see YouTube)
39/40 Which is why TWTR needs to either unapologetically tell the street a 10 year story (and take a near-term beating to kickstart it),
38/40 The street would hate that, as it will not prove near term revenue for TWTR.
37/40 That would take balls on behalf of TWTR. A real Bezos approach.
36/40 Build up the network of companies winning on TWTR alongside the consumers.
35/40 So, TWTR should fund it, investing hundreds of millions to enable the first waves of TWTR apps to focus on scale before revenue.
34/40 VC’s are not going to fund the TWTR app explosion though until they see more evidence.
33/40 This silly tweet storm — There should be awesome long form publishing tools for TWTR, and TWTR doesn’t need to build them.
32/40 Monetizing usage is Apple App store, enabling app makers to scale up fast & then make real money.
31/40 Monetizing the users is sponsored tweets. Monetizing usage is enabling services to thrive on the network.
30/40 TWTR should not be monetizing it’s users, it should be monetizing its usage. There’s a difference.
29/40 Let FB own sharing with your friends. TWTR can own publishing to the world.
28/40 Winning at TWTR scale isn’t making some billion in ad revenue. Winning at TWTR scale is owning one-to-many publishing, period.
27/40 What would Larry Page do w/ TWTR? What would Bezos do? What would Jobs do? What would Gates do?
26/40 IMO in rush to go public & provide liquidity, TWTR turned back on being platform & instead focused too early on monetizing users.
25/40 But, no one builds apps for TWTR anymore. People and companies just tweet.
24/40 TWTR should provide technology, tools, distribution, & monetization that enables thousands of new 1-to-many svcs to blossom. On TWTR.
23/40 Rather than going deep on specific verticals,
22/40 The future value of TWTR is directly correlated to future usage of the TWTR network.
21/40 The next @CNN, @ESPN, @NYTimes, @TheEconomist , @Disney , and @YouTube should be hatched on TWTR.
20/40 The next @andersoncooper should get her start on TWTR.
19/40 The next @justinbieber should be discovered on TWTR, not youtube.
18/40 @Pmarca should be leaving voice tweets. (maybe)
17/40 @serial should be heard, not just tweeting on TWTR.

16/40 @MileyCyrus should be live-streaming a concert to her fans on TWTR.
 @betashop

15/40 The Super Bowl and World Cup should be played on TWTR.
@betashop

14/40 The Interview should have been released on TWTR.
@betashop

13/40 TWTR should be the platform that distributes one to many.
 @betashop
12/40 Regardless of whether it’s short/long form text, video, voice, 7 seconds, 30 seconds, 12 minutes, or 120 minutes… @betashop
11/40 TWTR is not about status updates and it’s not about 140 characters. @betashop

10/40 TWTR should own the technology and platform that enables anyone to get their word out, one to many.
 @betashop

9/40 TWTR is not a media company. TWTR is (still) an emerging communications technology platform.
@betashop

8/40 TWTR is possibly the best one-to-many publishing platform on earth.
 @betashop
7/40 But, I’m a TWTR shareholder and TWTR fan, so here are my two cents.

6/40 I’m about as qualified to critique TWTR as @Dick is to critique @fab and @tweetsfromhem.
 @betashop
5/40 I am not privy to any insider TWTR info. I have no idea what the internal TWTR strategy is.  @betashop
4/40 I am still a TWTR investor. I've held my early shares and I've bought more. @betashop

3/40 I tried to buy TweetDeck in 2008 and ended up investing.
 @betashop
2/40 I should start by noting that I have been long on TWTR since 2007. @betashop
